thread.title: Yasay, Harris affirm stronger Phl-US ties
thread.title_full: Yasay, Harris affirm stronger Phl-US ties

title: Yasay, Harris affirm stronger Phl-US ties

organizations.name: center for strategic and international studies

text:
Yasay, Harris affirm stronger Phl-US ties By Pia Lee-Brago (The Philippine Star)   12:00am 
MANILA, Philippines - Foreign Affairs Secretary Perfecto Yasay Jr. and United States Pacific Command chief Admiral Harry Harris Jr. have affirmed the strong relations between the Philippines and the US even if President Duterte has been cool to Washington. 
Duterte has slammed the US for criticizing his bloody anti-drug war due to reported human rights violations and expressed preference to work closely with Beijing rather than Washington during the time of former US president Barack Obama. 
The Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) said yesterday the US would continue to work constructively and productively with the Philippines despite persistent human rights concerns under the Duterte administration. 
The DFA said Yasay met Harris at the USPACOM headquarters in Camp Smith in Hawaii on Friday. 
The DFA also quoted Harris as saying they continue to work with the Philippine military in humanitarian assistance and disaster relief operations, counter-terrorism and transnational crime operations. 
Murray Hiebert, a senior advisor and deputy director of the Southeast Asia Program at the US think tank Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), likewise noted Duterte’s “180-degree” turn as he suddenly stopped his anti-US rhetoric since President Donald Trump assumed office.   
Hiebert said the message could not be missed and it was “good.” 
State Department deputy spokesman Mark Toner said ties with the Philippines were one of the US’s core relationships. 
Human rights concerns, he said, could be discussed while moving forward the relationship between the two countries. 
The US, Toner said, has a long and enduring security relationship with the Philippines and Washington is always seeking to improve it. 
In October of last year, Duterte announced his “separation” from the US during a state visit to Beijing, but clarified later on Manila would not be severing ties with the US.
